name: Structured Data Capture Questionnaire Design
publisher: U.S. Office of the National Coordinator (ONC)'s Standards and Infrastructure (S&I) Structured Data Capture project
description: Defines how Questionnaire is used to reflect form definitions to be used within the ONC's Structured Data Capture standard. : Structured Data Capture Questionnaire Design

element.name: StructuredDataCaptureForm
element.formal: A structured set of questions intended to guide the collection of answers. The questions are ordered and grouped into coherent subsets, corresponding to the structure of the grouping of the underlying questions.
element.requirements: To support structured, hierarchical registration of data gathered using digital forms and other questionnaires.

constraint.name: UniqueLinkIds
constraint.human: The link ids for groups and questions must be unique within the questionnaire

element.formal: The logical id of the resource, as used in the url for the resoure. Once assigned, this value never changes.
element.comments: The only time that a resource does not have an id is when it is being submitted to the server using a create operation. Bundles always have an id, though it is usually a generated UUID.

element.formal: The metadata about the resource. This is content that is maintained by the infrastructure. Changes to the content may not always be associated with version changes to the resource.
unique id for the element within a resource (for internal references).

May be used to represent additional information that is not part of the basic definition of the element. In order to make the use of extensions safe and manageable, there is a strict set of governance  applied to the definition and use of extensions. Though any implementer is allowed to define an extension, there is a set of requirements that SHALL be met as part of the definition of the extension.
element.comments: There can be no stigma associated with the use of extensions by any application, project, or standard - regardless of the institution or jurisdiction that uses or defines the extensions.  The use of extensions is what allows the FHIR specification to retain a core level of simplicity for everyone.

element.formal: May be used to represent additional information that is not part of the basic definition of the element, and that modifies the understanding of the element that contains it. Usually modifier elements provide negation or qualification. In order to make the use of extensions safe and manageable, there is a strict set of governance applied to the definition and use of extensions. Though any implementer is allowed to define an extension, there is a set of requirements that SHALL be met as part of the definition of the extension. Applications processing a resource are required to check for modifier extensions.
element.comments: There can be no stigma associated with the use of extensions by any application, project, or standard - regardless of the institution or jurisdiction that uses or defines the extensions.  The use of extensions is what allows the FHIR specification to retain a core level of simplicity for everyone.

element.formal: The version specific identifier, as it appears in the version portion of the url. This values changes when the resource is created, updated, or deleted.
element.comments: The server assigns this value, and ignores what the client specifies, except in the case that the server is imposing version integrity on updates/deletes.

element.short: When the resource version last changed
element.formal: When the resource last changed - e.g. when the version changed.
element.comments: This value is always populated except when the resource is first being created. The server / resource manager sets this value; what a client provides is irrelevant.

element.short: Profiles this resource claims to conform to
element.formal: A list of profiles that this resource claims to conform to. The URL is a reference to Profile.url.
element.comments: It is up to the server and/or other infrastruture of policy to determine whether/how these claims are verified and/or updated over tiem.

element.short: Security Labels applied to this resource
element.formal: Security labels applied to this resource. These tags connect specific resources to the overall security policy and infrastructure.
element.comments: The security labels can be updated without changing the stated version of the resource.

element.formal: Tags applied to this resource. Tags are intended to to be used to identify and relate resources to process and workflow, and applications are not required to consider the tags when interpreting the meaning of a resource.
element.comments: The tags can be updated without changing the stated version of the resource.

element.short: A set of rules under which this content was created
element.formal: A reference to a set of rules that were followed when the resource was constructed, and which must be understood when processing the content.
element.comments: Asserting this rule set restricts the content to be only understood by a limited set of trading partners. This inherently limits the usefulness of the data in the long term. However the existing health eco-system is highly fractured, and not yet ready to define, collect, and exchange data in a generally computable sense. Wherever possible, implementers and/or specification writers should avoid using this element as much as possible.

element.formal: The base language in which the resource is written.
element.comments:
Language is provided to support indexing and accessibility (typically, services such as text to speech use the language tag). The html language tag in the narrative applies  to the narrative. The language tag on the resource may be used to specify the language of other presentations generated from the data in the resource

Not all the content has to be in the base language. The Resource.language should not be assumed to apply to the narrative automatically. If a language is specified, it should it also be specified on the div element in the html (see rules in HTML5 for information about the relationship between xml:lang and the html lang attribute).

element.short: Text summary of the resource, for human interpretation
element.formal: A human-readable narrative that contains a summary of the resource, and may be used to represent the content of the resource to a human. The narrative need not encode all the structured data, but is required to contain sufficient detail to make it "clinically safe" for a human to just read the narrative. Resource definitions may define what content should be represented in the narrative to ensure clinical safety.
element.comments: Contained resources do not have narrative. Resources that are not contained SHOULD have a narrative.

element.formal: These resources do not have an independent existence apart from the resource that contains them - they cannot be identified independently, and nor can they have their own independent transaction scope.
element.comments: This should never be done when the content can be identified properly, as once identification is lost, it is extremely difficult (and context dependent) to restore it again.

element.formal: This records identifiers associated with this question set that are defined by business processed and/ or used to refer to it when a direct URL reference to the resource itself is not appropriate (e.g. in CDA documents, or in written / printed documentation).
element.requirements: Need to allow connection to a wider workflow.

element.short: Logical id for this version of Questionnaire
element.formal: The version number assigned by the publisher for business reasons.  It may remain the same when the resource is updated.
element.requirements: In some cases, separate resource instances might be created for each version (if an older version can be maintained once a new version exists).
synonym: N/A - MIF rather than RIM level

element.formal: The lifecycle status of the questionnaire as a whole.

mapping.map: .statusCode (also whether there's a revisionControlAct - and possibly mood to distinguish "in progress" from "published)
.statusCode (also whether there's a revisionControlAct - and possibly mood to distinguish "in progress" from "published)

element.short: Identifies when this version of the form was created.  Changes whenever the form is updated.
element.formal: Identifies when this version of the form was created.  Changes whenever the form is updated.
Organization responsible for developing and maintaining the questionnaire.
element.requirements: Conveys responsibility for the questions and their organization and also helps evaluate the questionnaire's "authority".

element.name: group
element.formal: A collection of related questions (or further groupings of questions).
element.comments: The Questionnaire itself has one "root" group with the actual contents of the Questionnaire.  Information on this root group applies to the questionnaire as a whole.
element.requirements: Need to be able to logically group answers to grouped questions.

constraint.name: GroupHaveSubOrQuestions
constraint.human: Groups may either contain questions or groups but not both

element.comments: The definition may point directly to a computable or human-readable definition of the extensibility codes, or it may be a logical URI as declared in some other specification. element.short: To link questionnaire with questionnaire answers
element.formal: An identifier that is unique within the questionnaire allowing linkage to the equivalent group in a QuestionnaireAnswers resource.
element.comments: May be omitted if there is no expectation to link answers back to a questionnaire.  This *can* be a meaningful id (e.g. a LOINC code) but is not intended to have any meaning.  GUIDs or sequential numbers are appropriate here.
element.requirements: [[[QuestionnaireAnswers]]] does not require omitted groups to be included and may have some groups that repeat, so linkage based on position alone is not sufficient.

element.short: Name to be displayed for group
element.formal: The human-readable name for this section of the questionnaire.
element.comments: The title of the "root" group is the title for the questionnaire.
element.requirements: When including text for the questionnaire with the answers, sections may have a section header.

element.formal: May be used to represent additional information that is not part of the basic definition of the resource. element.short: Concept that represents this section on a questionnaire
element.formal: Identifies a how this group of questions is known in a particular terminology such as LOINC.
element.comments: The code(s) for the "root" group apply to the questionnaire as a whole.
element.requirements: Allows linking of groups of questions (and complete questionnaires) to formal terminologies.

binding.name: QuestionnaireGroupConcept
binding.description: Codes for questionnaires and groupings of questionnaire questions

element.formal: Additional text for the group, used for display purposes.
element.requirements: When including text for the questionnaire, each section may contain additional explanations are background text.

element.short: Must group be included in data results?
element.formal: If true, indicates that the group must be present and have required questions within it answered.  If false, the group may be skipped when answering the questionnaire.
Whether the group may occur multiple times in the instance, containing multiple sets of answers.
element.comments: When *repeats* is not specified, false is assumed.
element.requirements: Groups may be used to create set of (related) questions that can be repeated to give multiple answers to such a set.

element.formal: A sub-group within a group. The ordering of groups within this group is relevant.
element.requirements: Reports can consist of complex nested groups.

element.formal: Set of questions within this group. The order of questions within the group is relevant.
unique id for the element within a resource (for internal references).

May be used to represent additional information that is not part of the basic definition of the element, and that modifies the understanding of the element that contains it. Usually modifier elements provide negation or qualification. In order to make the use of extensions safe and manageable, there is a strict set of governance applied to the definition and use of extensions. Though any implementer is allowed to define an extension, there is a set of requirements that SHALL be met as part of the definition of the extension. Applications processing a resource are required to check for modifier extensions.

element.short: To link questionnaire with questionnaire answers
element.formal: An identifier that is unique within the questionnaire allowing linkage to the equivalent group in a [[[QuestionnaireAnswers]]] resource.
element.comments: May be omitted if there is no expectation to link answers back to a questionnaire.  This *can* be a meaningful id (e.g. a LOINC code) but is not intended to have any meaning.  GUIDs or sequential numbers are appropriate here.
element.requirements: [[[QuestionnaireAnswers]]] does not require omitted groups to be included and may have some groups that repeat, so linkage based on position alone is not sufficient.

element.short: Concept that represents this question on a questionnaire
element.formal: Identifies a how this question is known in a particular terminology such as LOINC.
element.requirements: Allows linking of questions (and their answers) to formal terminologies.

element.short: Text of the question as it is shown to the user
element.formal: Text of the question as it is shown to the user.
element.requirements: When including text for the questionnaire, each question may contain its actual question display text.

element.formal: The expected format of the answer, e.g. the type of input (string, integer) or whether a (multiple) choice is expected.
element.comments: Time is handled using "string".  File is handled using Attachment.  (Content can be sent as a contained binary).
element.requirements: Defines the format in which the user is to be prompted for the answer.

binding.name: AnswerFormat
binding.description: The expected format of an answer

mapping.map: N/A - MIF rather than RIM level
N/A - MIF rather than RIM level

element.short: Must group be included in data results?
element.formal: If true, indicates that the group must be present and have required questions within it answered.  If false, the group may be skipped when answering the questionnaire.
Whether the group may occur multiple times in the instance, containing multiple sets of answers.
element.comments: When *repeats* is not specified, false is assumed.
element.requirements: Groups may be used to create set of (related) questions that can be repeated to give multiple answers to such a set.

element.formal: Reference to a valueset containing the possible options.

mapping.map: Not supported - MIF/templating layer to capture value set
Not supported - MIF/templating layer to capture value set

element.formal: Nested group, containing nested question for this question. The order of groups within the question is relevant.
element.requirements: It is useful to have "sub-questions", questions which normally appear when certain answers are given and which collect additional details.

element.short: Identifies when this version of the form was created.  Changes whenever the form is updated.
element.formal: Identifies when this version of the form was created.  Changes whenever the form is updated.

mapping.map: Any element with @initial_state="hidden" and no rule that unhides the element
Any element with @initial_state="hidden" and no rule that unhides the element

element.name: specialGroup
element.comments: Are there form rendering mechanisms where it would be unreasonable to require systems to support this extension?.

mapping.map: Any element with @initial_state="hidden" and no rule that unhides the element
Any element with @initial_state="hidden" and no rule that unhides the element

element.comments: Time is handled using "string".  File is handled using Attachment.  (Content can be sent as a contained binary).
